==The history of ethics==
 
==The history of ethics==
    −
The formal study of ethics in a serious and analytical sense began with the early Greeks, and later Romans. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] and [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by [[Zeno of Citium|Zeno]] and the [[stoicism|stoics]].
+
The formal study of ethics in a serious and analytical sense began with the early Greeks and later by the Romans. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by the [[stoicism|stoics]] starting with [[Zeno of Citium]].
     
Although not developed in a formal and analytical sense, the subject of ethics was of great concern to the Hindu people in Ancient India. For the first time in world history, they described the highest ethical standards called "absolute ethics" by [[Albert Schweitzer]]. Millennia later, the [[Society of Friends]] or the Quakers reached as high as the [[Tirthankar|Jinas]]. <!-- I cannot be sure how POV this paragraph is, since its claims of superiority are all very vague-->
 
Although not developed in a formal and analytical sense, the subject of ethics was of great concern to the Hindu people in Ancient India. For the first time in world history, they described the highest ethical standards called "absolute ethics" by [[Albert Schweitzer]]. Millennia later, the [[Society of Friends]] or the Quakers reached as high as the [[Tirthankar|Jinas]]. <!-- I cannot be sure how POV this paragraph is, since its claims of superiority are all very vague-->
